input:
2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The doctor wants to know why I came in today, I should explain what’s been bothering me lately. I’ve been noticing things happening slowly and some twitching I can’t really control. I might be a little worried about what it all means, even if I’m not sure how to say it properly.

ANSWER: I’m 32, and I’m a girl. It’s just that for the past year or so, I’ve been feeling like I’m moving really slowly sometimes and my hand on the left just keeps trembling a bit. It’s been getting worse, and I guess I’m a little scared because it’s messing with my work and how I do everyday stuff.

input: 2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Can you tell me how these symptoms have been affecting your daily activities and if you've noticed anything else unusual or concerning about your health during this time?
output: Yeah, it’s been pretty tough. I keep dropping things or messing up details I used to do quickly, and I feel kind of sluggish all the time. Sometimes I get worried about what’s gonna happen next, and I don’t really feel like myself anymore. It’s messing with my work and just everyday stuff.

input: 2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have changed over the past year, and how they affect your daily activities or any other concerns you've noticed?
output: Um, well, I think it's been a little worse than when it started. I’ve been having a hard time doing stuff like typing or buttoning my clothes, and sometimes my hand feels all shaky, especially when I try to do something precise. It kind of makes me nervous because I’m worried it’s not just gonna stay the same or get worse. I’m also sometimes tired or restless at night, and I feel a bit worried about how this will go in the future.

input: 2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Can you tell me if your symptoms tend to get worse with rest, during activity, or at specific times of day, and whether anything you've tried seems to help or make them better?
output: Um, I think they don’t really get better or worse at certain times. Sometimes when I just rest, it feels a little the same, but other times it’s like it’s worse, especially in the mornings. I haven't really found anything that helps, nothing I’ve tried seems to make it better or worse, really.

input: 2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Are you experiencing any other symptoms such as rigidity, stiffness, any changes in gait or balance, facial expression, or autonomic symptoms like changes in blood pressure, sweating, or constipation?
output: Um, I think I might have some stiffness still, especially when I try to move certain parts, and I seem to kind of shuffle a bit more when I walk. Sometimes my face feels a little, I dunno, less expressive, and I’ve noticed I sweat more than before, but I’m not sure if that’s normal or not.

input: 2. A 32-year-old female software engineer presents with a 1.5-year history of progressive slowness in movement and subtle resting tremor in her left hand. She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Have you noticed if you have any issues with blood pressure regulation, such as feeling dizzy when standing, or problems with your digestion or urinary habits?
output: Well, I did feel a little dizzy sometimes when I stand up quickly, but it’s not all the time. I haven’t noticed much with my digestion or anything with my bathroom habits, really.

Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Have you experienced any symptoms like feeling dizzy or lightheaded when standing, changes in blood pressure, urinary urgency or incontinence, or constipation?
output: Um, I think I sometimes feel a bit dizzy when I get up quickly, but I’m not sure if it’s all the time. I haven't noticed much change in my blood pressure, though. As for other things like needing to go to the bathroom a lot or anything, I haven't really paid attention to that.

She also notes stiffness in her limbs and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as typing and buttoning clothes. Her symptoms began insidiously and have gradually impacted her daily activities and work performance. She denies any significant mood changes but admits to mild sleep disturbances and occasional drooling. There is no known family history of Parkinsonian disorders. Neurological examination reveals asymmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity more pronounced on the left, and decreased arm swing while walking. Brain imaging is normal, but functional imaging with DaTscan demonstrates reduced tracer uptake in the right striatum. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Are you comfortable discussing some management options to help manage your symptoms, and would you like to go over any particular concerns or questions you have about starting treatment or lifestyle modifications?
output: Um, I guess I’m a little nervous about starting any medicine, but I also don’t want things to get worse. I’m not sure what to expect or if there are things I should be doing differently every day.

Genetic analysis confirms a mutation linked to Parkinson disease 20, supporting the diagnosis of early-onset Parkinson’s disease.Are you experiencing any other autonomic symptoms, such as changes in blood pressure regulation (like feeling dizzy when standing), urinary issues, or constipation?
